>> You're pretty awesome though.

>> Well, yeah, okay,
technically you can't go past 10
but we'll call it 11.

>> What kind of weird
superstitious beliefs did you have?
>> This is the dumbest thing but I got

a turbo graphic 16, I
think it was in ninth grade

or something, Keith
Courage and Al Fazones,
there would be like I don't know,
some special thing that gave points
and it only came out every so often
but for some reason,
if one of us shouted the word "Chomp,"
then it tended to come out.

[laughs]
>> What!?

>> And so we were playing this
game, we would go, "Chomp!"

And then it would happen and
we'd be like, "See, it works!"
[laughs]
>> All right, we'll break it down,

four weird ways that you
can predict the world
using rogue science,
this is an article from Eamon Lahiri
that's on themodernrogue.com,

and I guess we'll rank
them according to what?
What's most surprising, or impressive,
or just which one we like the most, right?
>> Yeah, I think so.

Which one we think we would
get the most benefit out of.

[keyboard typing]
[whooshing]

>> This first one is
a study that indicates
that you can legitimately predict

the stock market's
performance, in the short term,
to a degree up to 86% accuracy,
based on moods on Twitter.
>> You can also tell when the stock market
is going to be really racist.
>> Yeah, that's right, filled with trolls.
They're all like, "Bye."
And then they're like, "SIKE."
To me, this seems like inherently true,
because, keep in mind, the stock market
is literally just a bunch of humans

making rational decisions
based on how they feel.
And yes, there are day-trading robots
that have algorithms and all that stuff,

and occasionally there's
runaway spikes and stuff,

but in general, it's
humans making decisions
that determine how the market does.

>> And, to borrow a
phrase that you often use,
it's essentially a shared hallucination.
>> Yeah, correct.

I mean it only has value
because we believe it has value

and if our feelings change
then the actual value changes.

So in this case they
did a large-scale survey
and they looked for 72 different words

indicating people's feelings,
whether they were uncertain,

and then they tested it on
stuff that you would expect.
For example, the day before an election,
people in general feeling very uncertain,

the day after the election,
they're feeling another way.

They found that periods of
calm, and a lot of use of words
that indicate that people are calm,
were reliably correlated

to either stock market
going up or going down.

It's great to have the
evidence to back it up,
it almost just rings so obviously true,
that to me it makes it less impressive,

but also, we're talking
about literally predicting

the stock market based on
Twitter, that's amazing.
>> Yeah, they have just mass scale,
10 million tweets over 11 months,
and they analyzed that, and again,

that accuracy level is
nothing to sniff at.
That is staggering.
>> It makes me wonder how much of that
is already being used,

'cause, you know, in a
world where machine learning
gets better and better,

and that data set just
gets larger and larger,
I a hundred percent believe this,
and it's our first one on the leaderboard.

Very impressive.
>> Absolutely.

[whooshing]
[keyboard typing]

Here's one that's also
kind of a no-brainer.

Google Street View being used
to tell how much you earn,
just by looking at your house.

>> So machine learning, using
an image analysis program,

was able to predict with a
higher degree of accuracy
than knowing people's demographics,
their sex, their ethnic background.

>> Their education, all the
things that are usually used

to factor into figuring
out how much someone makes,
this just analyzed a picture,
which, duh, you can drive by my house
and go, "Yeah, he's poor."
And then just keep going.
But it was very accurate.

>> It is, it is wild to
live in a world where

wherever you are, you can
just bust open a Zillow app
and know what everyone's house is worth.

>> Yeah.
>> Isn't that crazy?

>> Yep, they had also done
something like this similarly

using Google Street
View and people's cars.

They could get a similar
degree of accuracy
just by looking at your car and going,
"Oh, here's how much he makes."

>> Yeah, this one also I
think makes sense because
regardless of how much you make,
there's sort of a percentage that we tend

to allocate towards, you
know, our living expenses,
our house, or our car, or what have you.

And so, if you're making
a whole lot of money,
your housing accommodations will grow
to what you can afford to stay at.

All right, so where are we
on the impressiveness scale?
>> This one is interesting in that

it analyzes stuff that's
right there in front of you.

I like the Twitter one better.
>> Yeah.
>> I'm going to keep that at the top
'cause it's more large-scale, and I think
if you extrapolate out from that, it's--
>> Twitter one sounds like a magic trick
that shouldn't be possible.

>> It's got some terrifying
implications, too.
>> Yeah, yeah--

>> So I'm going to keep--
>> Twitter's still number one.

[keyboard typing]
[whooshing]
The size of human male organs
is inversely proportional
to the expected GDP of many countries.
This was a paper published out of Finland
that was originally conceived as a joke.
And then there was a shocking correlation
between average penis lengths
and the GDP of various countries.
>> It was a joke at first?

>> He started it as a joke
and now it's actual published.
At some point, he's like, wow, there is
a definite correlation here.
Not saying that means anything outside
of this appears to be the facts.

>> Okay, so, and again, you
say an inverse relation,
the smaller...
>> The more gifted you are in one way,
the less gifted you are financially.
>> A centimeter increase in penis length

corresponds to a 5-7%
fall in economic growth.
>> And keep in mind, this is on average,
per country, blah, blah, blah, blah.

Like, I don't know,
this seems like a weird,
curious statistical artifact.
>> You know what we should do,
we should get with the guys who drove

by the houses and use the
image analysis program, right--
>> And have them analyze other images.
>> And, no, no, no, just do that,
and then correlate it to say, okay,

just by looking at your
house, your penis is this big.

And then you put a little
thing out in the front yard.
>> I don't think that's how science works.
This one is last place on my leaderboard.

I feel like this is just
like, somebody found
a weird thing, although those formulas
look very impressive in the paper.
>> There are actual mathematical formulas.

>> I feel like he's trying
to compensate for something
with the very long formulas.

>> Well, you know what they
say about mathematicians.
>> Now we know how much money he made.

[whooshing]
[keyboard typing]
>> Here's a really fascinating one.

Taking the screams of babies
and using those patterns

of escalation when
dealing with their parents
to map out human aggression.
>> This is another one of those
that once you wrap your mind around it,
it kind of does make sense.
Basically the thesis is that what happens

on the micro-scale, essentially
happens on the macro-scale.
In other words, you map out the escalation
of a child increasingly getting upset
and adapting to try to get the attention

of a bigger, slower
moving, less interested
in taking care of them party,

getting the attention of
a parent, in other words--
>> Or a government.
>> Exactly, exactly tracks to in Poland.
You can see the run-up exactly follows
that screaming baby pattern of escalation.
>> Timing and intensity.

>> And Mother Russia just
takes longer and longer
to turn around and do anything about it.

That same pattern also
happens in, get this,
predatory traders on the stock market,

as they do a run-up
trying to take over GE,
a General Electric, at one point.
And according to the original article
even the Bloody Sunday attacks.
You could see that there was an escalation
that exactly maps onto the way
babies interact with adults.

>> The implications of
this are staggering, right?
I think this one is my favorite

because it is an algorithmic
model of human aggression.

>> Yeah, this one might
be the most capital I
important thing to figure out,
like from a philosophical standpoint.

>> But you can't incorporate
it into your show.
>> Well, yes and.

But also, man, predicting
the stock market!

What could be a bigger, more

I will give this a solid
second place in my leaderboard.
